content:
If we have a indexed monoidal category (V,⊗) (\mathbb{V}, \otimes) (V,⊗) over a cartesian monoidal category S\mathrm{S}S then one can construct the external tensor product (see here) where given X,Y∈S \mathrm{X}, \mathrm{Y} \in \mathrm{S}X,Y∈S, we have (something like):

⊠:VX→VY→VX×Y\boxtimes : \mathbb{V}_{\mathrm{X}} \rightarrow \mathbb{V}_{\mathrm{Y}} \rightarrow \mathbb{V}_{X \times Y}⊠:VX​→VY​→VX×Y​ {Vx}x∈X⊠{Wy}y∈Y↦{Vx⊗Wy}(x,y)∈X×Y\{V_x\}_{x \in \mathrm{X}} \boxtimes \{W_y\}_{y \in \mathrm{Y}} \mapsto \{V_x \otimes W_y\}_{(x, y) \in \mathrm{X} \times \mathrm{Y}}{Vx​}x∈X​⊠{Wy​}y∈Y​↦{Vx​⊗Wy​}(x,y)∈X×Y​

Does anyone know of any generalization where Y\mathrm{Y}Y can be dependent on X\mathrm{X}X and the target is not over the product but the dependent sum?

Well, just as V⊠WV\boxtimes WV⊠W is defined by pulling VVV and WWW both back to X×YX\times YX×Y and tensoring them there, if you have Y∈S/XY\in S/XY∈S/X and V∈VXV \in \mathbb{V}_XV∈VX​ with W∈VYW\in \mathbb{V}_YW∈VY​, you could just pull VVV back along the projection Y→XY\to XY→X and tensor it there with WWW.
True! I was curious if you (or anyone else) has come across this construction in your work?
Doesn't ring any immediate bells.
I was hoping it might be related to the indexed coproduct in V\mathbb{V}V, for instance that sort of one-sided pullback looks reminiscent of the projection formula.
You could push it forward again along something, but that starts to look more like the canceling tensor product rather than the external one.

Callan McGill said:

If we have a indexed monoidal category (V,⊗) (\mathbb{V}, \otimes) (V,⊗) over a cartesian monoidal category S\mathrm{S}S then one can construct the external tensor product (see here) where given X,Y∈S \mathrm{X}, \mathrm{Y} \in \mathrm{S}X,Y∈S, we have (something like):

⊠:VX→VY→VX×Y\boxtimes : \mathbb{V}_{\mathrm{X}} \rightarrow \mathbb{V}_{\mathrm{Y}} \rightarrow \mathbb{V}_{X \times Y}⊠:VX​→VY​→VX×Y​ {Vx}x∈X⊠{Wy}y∈Y↦{Vx⊗Wy}(x,y)∈X×Y\{V_x\}_{x \in \mathrm{X}} \boxtimes \{W_y\}_{y \in \mathrm{Y}} \mapsto \{V_x \otimes W_y\}_{(x, y) \in \mathrm{X} \times \mathrm{Y}}{Vx​}x∈X​⊠{Wy​}y∈Y​↦{Vx​⊗Wy​}(x,y)∈X×Y​

Does anyone know of any generalization where Y\mathrm{Y}Y can be dependent on X\mathrm{X}X and the target is not over the product but the dependent sum?

It seems like you have to consider a nested indexing then: V\mathbb VV is not an indexed monoidal category but an indexed monoidal indexed category!
In this way you can talk about VY\mathbb V_YVY​ being 'dependent' on VX\mathbb V_XVX​. I don't see a slick way to define ⊠\boxtimes⊠ in this case, I mean as a known kind of structure to associate to this indexing

Mmh ok maybe it's easier than I thought, what about this?
image.png
Here I identify Σ\SigmaΣ with the domain opfibration C↓→C\cal C^\downarrow \to CC↓→C
V\mathbb VV is monoidally fibred over C\cal CC (and its equivalent to your indexed monoidal cat with the same name)
Additionally, you have W\mathbb WW which is also fibred over C↓\cal C^\downarrowC↓, so for any Y→XY \to XY→X (YYY dependent over XXX) we have a category WY→X\mathbb W_{Y \to X}WY→X​

Then ⅀ (I'm very happy this symbol exists in Unicode) has type

⅀:WY→X→VY⅀:\mathbb W_{Y \to X} \to \mathbb V_Y⅀:WY→X​→VY​
It's not exactly what you want but how do you make VY→X\mathbb V_{Y \to X}VY→X​ typecheck otherwise?
Just for comparison, the external tensor product can also be presented in a similar manner: image.png
and of course there's no need for the bottom opfibration here image.png to be dom, it could be anything you have giving you Sigma types
(Like, for instance, ×\times×)

Notice it makes sense to consider this bottom opfibration to be part of a span C←D→C\cal C \leftarrow D \to CC←D→C where the left leg is a fibration and the right leg is an opfibration. Then you extend this up and you could make W\mathbb WW fibered over V\mathbb VV
image.png
Maybe I misunderstood, but I don't think Callan suggested that VY\mathbb{V}_YVY​ could be dependent on VX\mathbb{V}_XVX​, only that YYY could be dependent on XXX.
Uhm right

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

Then ⅀ (I'm very happy this symbol exists in Unicode) has type

⅀:WY→X→VY⅀:\mathbb W_{Y \to X} \to \mathbb V_Y⅀:WY→X​→VY​

So actually this is not as bad as I thought
